newsitem.title: GERMANY: Santer backs strict view of EMU deficit goal-paper.
newsitem.headline: Santer backs strict view of EMU deficit goal-paper.

text.p: European Commission president Jacques Santer at the weekend backed a strict interpretation of the deficit criterion for Europe's planned currency union.
In a summary of an article to be published in Sunday's edition of Berlin newspaper Tagesspiegel, Santer was quoted as saying, "I do believe that one has to handle this criterion restrictively."
Germany has been demanding strict compliance with the Maastricht Treaty deficit target which says nations' deficits should not exceed three percent of gross domestic product.
The target is designed to protect the credibility of the new euro currency.

But quibbling over exactly what the Treaty's "three" percent reference value means has become a hot topic as Germany struggles to meet its 1997 deficit goal of 2.9 percent due to high unemployment and fragile growth.
Santer however said he saw no reason to doubt that Germany would meet the entry requirements.
Santer also said that talk about postponing the scheduled January 1, 1999 launch date was contrived.
However Santer said more work was needed to inform the public about the planned currency euro.
